thread.title: Westbury man who claimed police brutality headed to prison
thread.title_full: Westbury man who claimed police brutality headed to prison | Newsday

author: Bridget Murphy
title: Westbury man who claimed police brutality headed to prison
text:
A Westbury man who was at the center of 2014 police brutality allegations that ended in a Nassau cop’s acquittal pleaded guilty to a felony assault charge Wednesday in a separate case and will be heading to prison. 
The Nassau district attorney’s office said Kyle Howell, 23, pleaded guilty in Nassau County Court to a second-degree assault charge after an arrest last year on robbery, assault, weapon and drug possession charges. Most Popular Man dies in Montauk Highway crash, police say Cops: Jeep driver ejected in 2-vehicle crash Woman lied about being raped, police say Woman charged after crashing car into woods Village moves to join neighboring fire district 
Under the plea, a judge said he would sentence Howell to two years in prison and three years of post-release supervision, prosecutors said Thursday. Story Records: Police accuser facing drug charges Story Man who sued cops pleads not guilty to robbery Story Cops: Man who accused cop of assault arrested 
Howell’s attorney couldn’t be immediately reached for comment Thursday. 
Nassau police arrested Howell last April, charging him with robbing two people of $400 at knife point during an alleged drug deal in Great Neck Plaza. 
Police alleged at the time that Howell met a man and a woman in a car to sell them drugs, but Howell got in the back seat of the vehicle and held a knife to the man’s throat, demanding money. 
advertisement | advertise on newsday 
Howell then cut both of the male’s hands with a knife when the man tried to push him away, according to police. 
The woman then gave Howell the money and he fled, authorities also had alleged. 
Police found Howell with 17 Xanax pills and a bag of cocaine when they arrested him later, according to court documents in the case, which also said Howell had denied ownership of the drugs. 
Howell had said publicly after his April 19 arrest that he was “being framed,” an allegation Nassau police strongly refuted. 
Records show a federal lawsuit that Howell previously filed against the county and two Nassau police officers remains pending. He has alleged he was the victim of police brutality during an April 2014 traffic stop that a store’s surveillance camera caught on video. 
In 2015, a Nassau judge acquitted police Officer Vincent LoGiudice of assault charges after a trial in which prosecutors had alleged he beat Howell during that Westbury car stop. 
Howell still faces two misdemeanor drug charges from a November 2016 arrest, according to court records. In that case, police charged him with criminal possession of a controlled substance in the seventh degree and fifth-degree marijuana possession. 
Court records show Howell also faces a misdemeanor drug possession charge from an arrest in January. Get the Newsday Now newsletter!
